> Why would they need to be logically decoupled?  The
> DNA string could could contain instructions for
> building particular structures, and developmental rule
> sets, right?

Yeah, sure, and this is the way its normally done I think. I want to split
 them up in order to take advantage of coevolution. Also this way different
 developmental systems can be applied to a bunch of different chromosomes.
> 
> > This is along the lines of some of
> > DeJong's and also Ficici's
> > work over at Brandeis (coevolving teacher/learner
> > pairs).
> 
> Not familiar with this work, but I'll head on over to
> CiteSeer and have a look. 

Most of this is available online on Prof. Pollack (at Brandeis)'s website.
 Couldnt tell you the URL off hand, sorry.

> > This dichotomy is really important in biology, i.e.,
> > DNA is almost
> > completely useless information without the
> > developmental system that it is
> > paired with. And the two definately evolved
> > together.
> 
> But the DNA encodes for the developmental system in
> resides in, doesn't it?  I guess I don't see a clear
> dichotomy...maybe you could elaborate.

Yeah, but without an already existing system to utilize the DNA(e.g. the
 mother), it will never turn into a baby. So there is this coevolutionary
 chicken-and-egg problem.

> > Personally, I'd love to do a PhD thesis on this idea
> > if I can get into a
> > good graduate school.
> 
> You're a senior at UT now?  Where are you thinking of
> applying to grad school?
>

Yup. The pickings are kinda slim for this evolutionary and developmental
 systems stuff. I'm gonna apply to some UK schools: University College
 London, Sussex, and Birmingham. In the US: Brandeis and MIT. And maybe some
 others, havent really decided yet. 

Joe
